title: 105_hr3110
content: The "Skilled Workforce Enhancement Act of 1998" allows for a tax credit for expenses related to training employees in highly skilled metalworking trades. This credit is added as a new section in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The highly skilled metalworking trades training credit allows for a tax credit of 80% of training expenses for qualified trained employees, with a maximum credit of $100,000 per employee. The employer must be a small employer to qualify for this credit. The tax credit for highly skilled metalworking trades training applies to small employers who have qualified trained employees with at least 8,000 hours of training. The tax credit applies to small employers with trained employees in highly skilled metalworking trades like precision machinists and tool designers. Training expenses include wages for services in these trades. The tax credit applies to small employers with trained employees in highly skilled metalworking trades. Wages for services performed by apprentices in such trades are included in the training expenses. The training period is defined as a 4-year period from the start of employment as an apprentice. A small employer is defined as having an average of 500 or fewer employees during the taxable year. The tax credit applies to small employers with trained employees in highly skilled metalworking trades. Wages for services performed by apprentices in such trades are included in the training expenses. The training period is defined as a 4-year period from the start of employment as an apprentice. All persons treated as a single employer under certain sections shall be treated as 1 employer. Wages taken into account for the tax credit cannot be used for other credits. The credit for training expenses for employees in highly skilled trades is made part of the general business credit. The tax credit applies to small employers with trained employees in highly skilled metalworking trades. No deduction is allowed for expenses equal to the amount of the credit determined for the taxable year under section 45D(a). A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Code. The tax credit applies to small employers for training expenses in highly skilled metalworking trades. The amendments made by this section apply to expenses paid after the enactment date in taxable years ending after that date.
